content.title: Sick Sinus Syndrome
content.summary: Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) encompasses a spectrum of sinus node dysfunction including sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, sinoatrial exit block, and chronotropic incompetence, often alternating with atrial tachyarrhythmias (tachy-brady syndrome). Symptomatic patients require permanent pacemaker implantation.
key_points: Sinus node dysfunction causing inappropriate bradycardia
Tachy-brady syndrome: alternating bradycardia and atrial tachyarrhythmias
Symptoms: syncope, presyncope, fatigue, exercise intolerance, palpitations
Chronotropic incompetence: inadequate HR increase with exercise
Permanent pacemaker is treatment for symptomatic patients
content.statement: Sick sinus syndrome is a manifestation of sinus node dysfunction causing symptomatic bradycardia, often with superimposed atrial tachyarrhythmias (tachy-brady syndrome), requiring permanent pacemaker implantation for symptom relief.

explanation.intuition: The sinus node is the heart's natural pacemaker. In SSS, this pacemaker becomes unreliable - sometimes too slow, sometimes with long pauses. Many patients also develop AF (the tachy in tachy-brady). The sinus node can't keep up after a tachycardia terminates, causing long pauses and syncope.
explanation.key_insight: The tachy-brady relationship is key: atrial fibrillation and flutter commonly coexist with SSS, and the pause after spontaneous termination of AF can be dangerously long. This dual problem requires both pacing for bradycardia and rate/rhythm control for tachycardia.
explanation.technical_details: SSS results from fibrosis, ischemia, or degeneration affecting the sinus node and surrounding atrial tissue. Intrinsic sinus node dysfunction is distinguished from extrinsic causes (drugs, vagal tone) using atropine/isoproterenol testing. Corrected sinus node recovery time (CSNRT) >550ms indicates dysfunction.

definitions_glossary.sick_sinus_syndrome: Spectrum of sinus node dysfunction causing symptomatic bradycardia
definitions_glossary.tachy_brady_syndrome: SSS with alternating bradycardia and atrial tachyarrhythmias
definitions_glossary.sinus_bradycardia: Sinus rhythm <60 bpm; symptomatic if <40 bpm with symptoms
definitions_glossary.sinus_pause: Failure of sinus node to fire; pause >3 seconds is significant
definitions_glossary.sinoatrial_exit_block: Impulse generated but blocked from reaching atrium
definitions_glossary.chronotropic_incompetence: Inadequate heart rate increase with exercise (<80% predicted max HR)
definitions_glossary.sinus_node_recovery_time: SNRT; time for sinus node to resume after overdrive pacing
definitions_glossary.CSNRT: Corrected SNRT (SNRT minus cycle length); >550ms is abnormal
definitions_glossary.permanent_pacemaker: PPM; device providing electrical stimulation for bradycardia
definitions_glossary.DDD_pacemaker: Dual-chamber pacing (atrium and ventricle) with sensing and response
definitions_glossary.VVI_pacemaker: Single-chamber ventricular pacing; associated with pacemaker syndrome
definitions_glossary.pacemaker_syndrome: Symptoms from loss of AV synchrony with VVI pacing

pathophysiology.mechanism: Sinus node and/or surrounding atrial tissue dysfunction from fibrosis, ischemia, or degeneration

manifestations.sinus_pause_arrest: Failure of sinus node firing >3 seconds
manifestations.SA_exit_block: PP interval is exact multiple of preceding PP (blocked beat)
manifestations.chronotropic_incompetence: HR fails to rise appropriately with exercise

clinical_presentation: Syncope or presyncope (from pauses or bradycardia)
ECG_findings: Sinus pauses or arrest (>3 seconds significant)

diagnostic_workup.event_recorder: Extended monitoring for less frequent symptoms
diagnostic_workup.EP_study: SNRT, CSNRT; rarely needed if clinical diagnosis clear

differential_diagnosis: AV block (different level of conduction disease)

indications: Symptomatic bradycardia without reversible cause (Class I)
Syncope with SSS documented or suspected (Class IIa)

DDD_preferred.rationale: Maintains AV synchrony; reduces AF incidence vs VVI

pacing_mode.AAI_rarely_used: Risk of future AV block development

tachy_brady_management.principle: Pacemaker enables safe rate/rhythm control therapy
tachy_brady_management.rate_control: Beta-blockers or CCBs (now safe with pacemaker backup)
tachy_brady_management.rhythm_control: Antiarrhythmics, cardioversion, AF ablation if indicated
tachy_brady_management.anticoagulation: Based on CHA2DS2-VASc for stroke prevention

definition.@value: A spectrum of sinus node dysfunction causing symptomatic bradycardia, often with alternating atrial tachyarrhythmias, requiring permanent pacemaker implantation

scopeNote.@value: Covers clinical manifestations, diagnostic approach, and pacemaker therapy for sick sinus syndrome

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical manifestations of sick sinus syndrome
Identify ECG findings consistent with sinus node dysfunction
Distinguish intrinsic from extrinsic causes of bradycardia
Apply indications for permanent pacemaker implantation
Select appropriate pacing mode (DDD vs VVI)
clinical_pearls: Pause after AF termination = classic tachy-brady presentation
Always review meds - beta-blockers and CCBs are common causes
Dual-chamber pacing (DDD) reduces AF incidence compared to VVI
Pacemaker enables safe use of rate/rhythm control drugs
Symptoms must correlate with documented bradycardia for pacing indication
common_misconceptions: All sinus bradycardia is SSS - many healthy people (athletes) have slow HR
Pacemaker treats the AF in tachy-brady - no, it treats bradycardia; AF needs separate therapy
VVI pacing is adequate - DDD is preferred to maintain AV synchrony
